be.kdg.se3.services.railway

Class RouteServiceProxy

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kdg.se3.services.railway.RouteServiceProxy

  • public class RouteServiceProxy
extends java.lang.Object
    Proxy that simulates a call to the route service
    The proxy mimics the real HTTP service as close as possible: it is called with a URL and returns JSON
    The URL does not exist and no real HTTP call is made; the proxy just holds the calling thread for some millis to simulate network latency
    A call to www.services4se3.com/railway/route/rideId will return a JSON with the route for the specified id (int)
    The JSON response has the following structure

    {
    rideId: the ride for which the route was requested (int) ,
    routeSections: the consecutive sections to be taken for this ride ,
      [
       {
         sectionId: the section (int) ,
         speed: the speed to be taken into account on this section in m/s (int)
       },
       ...
     ]
    }

    Requested rideId's are supposed to fall in the range [1-500]
    The service returns data in realistic ranges, but the data is random generated so subsequent calls with the same id will return in most cases different data
    Some id's do not result in random behaviour:
    - If you use the constructor without params, rideId's 1 to 10 will return a fixed result
    - If you use the second constructor, you can supply a set of routes as a map. Each rideId in the map must be coupled to an array of Integer that is interpreted as follows: (idOfSection1, speedOnSection1, idOfSection2, speedOnSection2, ...)
    - rideId 11 will always raise an IOException to simulate a communication error
    - rideId's outside the range [1-500] return an error JSON response (see below) indicating an unknown rideId
    - rideId's that can not be converted to a number will return an error JSON response (see below) indicating an invalid rideId
    - an incorrect URL will raise an IOException

    An error JSON response indicates that the call succeeded but no sensible data could be returned. It has the following format
    {
    error: the type of error: UnknownRideId or InvalidRideId (string),
    description: a description of the error (string)
    }

      • get

        public java.lang.String get(java.lang.String url)
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Mimics a get on a remote HTTP service using the supplied URL.
        Parameters:
        url - the endpoint of the call in a valid format (see class documentation)
        Returns:
        a data or error response in the correct JSON format (see class documentation)
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if invocation fails (wrong endpoint URL or unexpected communcation/service failure)
